title: Rerun’s open-source AI platform for robots, drones and cars revs up with $17M seed
summary:
- Rerun, a Stockholm-based startup, secured $17 million in seed funding for its open-source platform designed for 'Physical AI'.
- The funding round was led by Point Nine capital, increasing total funding to $20.2 million.
- Rerun's platform manages multimodal data including video, 3D scenes, and more to aid AI in physical environments, addressing issues between AI and physical data integration.
- Its tools enable better debugging by allowing developers to visualize bot movements and data from real-world sensors.
- The company aims to create a 'data flywheel' for improved AI training outcomes as more robots are deployed.
- Rerun's visualizations have been utilized in projects by Meta, Google, and Hugging Face, among others.
- The startup's team includes veterans from major tech companies like Apple, AWS, and Unity, focusing on specialized tools for AI developers.

sources.title: Rerun’s open-source AI platform for robots, drones and cars revs up with $17M seed

title: Nvidia Unveils RTX Pro 6000 GPU and Vera Rubin Platform for AI Advancements
summary:
- Nvidia announces the RTX Pro Blackwell series of GPUs, including the RTX Pro 6000 for workstations.
- RTX Pro 6000 features 96GB of GDDR7 memory and requires 600W of power.
- It supports PCIe Gen 5 and DisplayPort 2.1, with enhanced RT cores and Tensor cores.
- Designed for professionals in game development and AI workloads, with variants in Max-Q and server editions.
- Pricing for the RTX Pro 6000 is not yet set; it will be available in April through partners like [PNY](https://www.theverge.com/news/631868/nvidia-rtx-pro-6000-blackwell-gpu-professionals) and [TD Synnex](https://www.theverge.com/news/631868/nvidia-rtx-pro-6000-blackwell-gpu-professionals), with manufacturer availability in May.
- Cloud service providers will offer the server variant later this year, with the rest of the RTX Pro Blackwell lineup available in summer.

- Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang introduced the new Vera Rubin platform at the GTC developer event in San Jose.
- The platform includes Nvidia’s first custom-designed CPU, “Vera,” and two new “Rubin” GPUs, doubling inference performance compared to last year’s Blackwell.
- Huang noted a growing demand for rapid data processing in AI inference, stating that the computation needed is 100 times more than previously anticipated.
- Nvidia also announced Blackwell Ultra, a more powerful GPU expected to launch in the second half of 2025.
- Project Digits will launch summer 2025 with versions for developers to run AI models more efficiently.
- A new family of open-source reasoning models called Nemotron was introduced, optimized for enterprise tasks.

sources.title: Nvidia’s RTX Pro 6000 has 96GB of VRAM and 600W of power
Nvidia’s Vera Rubin represents a big bet on real-time AI reasoning

title: Hackers are ramping up attacks using year-old ServiceNow security bugs to target unpatched systems
summary:
- Hackers exploiting three ServiceNow vulnerabilities (CVE-2024-4879, CVE-2024-5178, CVE-2024-5217).
- Vulnerabilities disclosed in May 2024 and patched in July 2024.
- 70% of recent activity targeted systems in Israel; also observed in Germany, Japan, and Lithuania.
- Vulnerabilities can provide full database access to ServiceNow instances.
- ServiceNow reports no observed customer impact from attacks.
- Targeted sectors include private companies and government agencies worldwide.

title: Toronto’s hottest tourist attraction is… a tree named Rodney
summary:

- The tree gained viral attention after a Google Maps listing was shared on Reddit's r/MadeMeSmile subreddit.
- One visitor traveled from the U.K. to see Rodney, praising the experience.
- Another reviewer called it the “real gem of Toronto,” above famous landmarks like the CN Tower.
- Visitors are warned to avoid a similar but inferior tree nearby, known as an imposter.

title: Airbyte launches new connectors to help companies better leverage their data
summary:
- Open-source data movement company [Airbyte](https://airbyte.com/) is launching new connectors for enterprises to utilize data effectively in the age of AI.
- New features include support for unstructured data transfer from Google Drive and SharePoint, along with compatibility with [Apache Iceberg](https://iceberg.apache.org/).
- A new connector bundle for enterprise customers includes data connector pipelines for applications like NetSuite, SAP, ServiceNow, and Workday.
- Airbyte provides enterprises with control over their data, allowing them to protect sensitive information during data transfer.
- The company was founded in 2020 and has raised over $181 million in venture capital, serving more than 7,000 enterprise customers.

title: TikTok to Launch Amber Alerts in Users’ For You Feeds
summary:
- TikTok partners with the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC) to deliver Amber Alerts in users’ For You feeds in the U.S.
- Alerts will activate based on users' location via IP address and include key details like child’s photo and last known location.
- Nationwide launch follows a successful pilot in Texas with over 20 million views and 2.5 million visits to NCMEC’s website from August to December 2024.
- TikTok is donating advertising credits to help amplify NCMEC’s messaging on missing children and youth safety.
- The initiative aims to leverage TikTok's massive teen user base, potentially increasing awareness and responsiveness to Amber Alerts.
- The alerts will include a photo of the child and the option to call 911.
- Other apps like Uber, Waze, Facebook, Instagram, and X have also integrated AMBER Alerts.

title: Do school phone bans actually work? A new study says not really
summary:
- A new study published in *The Lancet* found no evidence that banning cellphones in schools improves student well-being or grades in reading and math.
- The study examined 30 U.K. schools, with 20 restricting cellphone use and 10 allowing it.
- No significant difference in mental well-being was found between students in restrictive and permissive schools, though more cellphone and social media use correlated with lower mental well-being.
- Recommendations suggest focusing on helping students navigate a world with cellphones, instead of implementing bans.

sources.title: Do school phone bans actually work? A new study says not really

title: This digital notebook simulates E Ink screens to reduce distractions
summary:
- The XP-Pen Magic Note Pad simulates E Ink screens using a full-color LCD with three modes: black-and-white, light color, and ink paper mode.
- The device features a nano-etched surface to reduce glare and reflectivity, aiming to replicate the feel of writing on paper.
- Priced at $439.99, the Magic Note Pad is currently available for a limited time at $359.99 and includes the X3 Pro Pencil 2 stylus, which doesn't require charging.

title: Netflix’s CEO Talks Competitors and Live Sports Strategy
summary:

- He questioned HBO's rebranding to 'Max' and suggested it would reduce to just HBO in the long run.

title: Tesla recalls Cybertrucks for exterior panels that fall off
summary:
- Tesla recalls approximately 46,000 Cybertrucks due to a potential issue with exterior steel trim panels that can peel off while driving.
- The recall is a response to warranty claims and a safety hazard identified by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA).
- Tesla plans to use a different structural adhesive and a nut to secure the panels during the recall repair, which will be performed at no cost to owners.
- This is the eighth recall for the Cybertruck, following several past issues related to adhesive failures and other components coming loose.
- The recall was agreed upon on March 11, after further investigation into customer complaints sparked by NHTSA.

summary:

title: Australian government agencies could be customers of Israeli spyware, research suggests
summary:
- Australian agencies may be customers of Israeli spyware from Paragon Solutions according to a new report.
- In January, Meta reported over 90 individuals had their WhatsApp accounts compromised, raising concerns about potential Australian targets.
- The Citizen Lab identified two IP addresses in Australia linked to Paragon's Graphite spyware, suggesting possible use by government agencies.
- Paragon’s software provides full access to messaging apps and is exclusively sold to governments, not private enterprises.
- Australian government departments, including Home Affairs and the Signals Directorate, reportedly have no connections to Paragon Solutions.
- Paragon's executive chairman emphasized compliance with laws and regulations in their operations.

title: Tesla Recalls Over 46,000 Cybertrucks Amid Safety Concerns and Calls for Oversight
summary:
- Families of Tesla crash victims are urging the US Department of Transportation to maintain a reporting rule for crashes involving autonomous vehicles.
- They express concerns about Elon Musk's influence potentially weakening oversight of Tesla's technologies.
- The letter to Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy cites fears that the Biden-era rule may be discarded, benefiting Tesla's reporting advantages.
- Since the rule's implementation, Tesla has reported over 1,800 crashes, accounting for most fatal crashes reported to NHTSA.
- The families highlight the importance of continued oversight to ensure safety for drivers using Tesla's Autopilot and Full Self-Driving features.
- Tesla has issued a recall for 46,096 Cybertrucks in the US due to a defect causing steel trim to come loose.
- The recall affects all Cybertrucks manufactured between November 13th, 2023, and February 27th, 2025.
- Approximately 1% of the impacted vehicles have been identified as having the trim defect.
- This is the eighth recall for the Cybertruck since its launch in December 2023.
- The issue has been reported by several owners and documented in forums and YouTube teardown videos.
- Tesla will replace the cant rail for free using new adhesive and clamping the panel to ensure safety.

summary:
- Adapty launches FunnelFox to help app makers acquire customers via web experiences and quizzes.
- FunnelFox allows app makers to bypass App Store fees by directing customers to download their app after payment.
- Adapty tracked $20 million in revenue during testing with 100 customers, reportedly doubling their revenue from mobile in-app purchases.
- The company offers features like drag-and-drop tools and AI suggestions for building customer acquisition funnels.
- Adapty operates on a revenue-sharing model with tiered pricing for FunnelFox not yet specified.
- The startup is profitable and has raised $2.5 million in capital, tracking $1.2 billion in revenue across 10,000 applications.

summary:

title: Meta AI Launches in Europe with Limitations
summary:
- Meta AI is launching in Europe after a delay of almost one year.
- The rollout includes 41 European countries and 21 overseas territories, limited to text-based chat features.
- Previous launch attempts were paused due to privacy concerns raised by Ireland's regulations.
- Users can brainstorm, plan trips, and answer questions using the web, but cannot generate or edit images.
- The assistant has not been trained on EU user data.
- Meta is committed to collaborate with regulators for future expansions of AI capabilities in Europe.
- Meta AI is launching in the EU with limited features compared to the U.S. version.
- Features include a chatbot function available in six languages, but creative functions like image generation are not included.
- The rollout extends to 27 EU countries and an additional 14 European nations, plus 21 overseas territories.
- Meta has faced regulatory challenges regarding data usage for training AI due to GDPR privacy regulations.
- The EU version of Meta AI was not trained on local user data, and therefore will not seek user consent.

title: We’ve entered a forever war with bird flu
summary:
- Avian influenza H5N1 evolving rapidly, adapting to mammals.
- Human cases in the US rising, especially among farmworkers; risk of human-to-human transmission increasing.
- Over 70 confirmed human cases in the US, with recent hospitalizations and one death.
- Virus infected nearly 1,000 dairy herds since its detection in cows in 2024.
- A new D1.1 genotype of the virus spreading; potential for more severe human cases.
- Bird flu detected in domestic animals and wildlife, including cats and rodents.
- Experts suggest H5N1 is likely endemic, making eradication impossible.
- Calls for increased surveillance on farms and monitoring of potential animal reservoirs.
- Vaccination and biosecurity measures remain crucial for managing the outbreak.

title: UK watchdog bans ‘shocking’ ads in mobile games that objectified women
summary:

title: The Rise of the AI Manager
summary:
- AI is reshaping the role of knowledge workers, enabling them to become managers of AI agents rather than just individual contributors.
- AI systems are capable of data analysis, report generation, and decision-making, demonstrating their potential as team members.
- Effective management of AI requires both technical skills and soft skills, merging tactical oversight with an understanding of human collaboration.
- Concerns about mass unemployment due to AI are contrasted with the idea that increased efficiency may create new opportunities, similar to trends observed during the industrial revolution.
- Preparing for an AI-centric economy emphasizes the need for enhanced education, AI literacy in the workforce, and self-driven learning for individuals vulnerable to job disruption.

title: Crypto Investments and Major Hacks: Bybit’s $1.4 Billion Heist and MGX's $2 Billion Binance Investment
summary:

- $4.23 million has already been awarded to bounty hunters.
- The hack is suspected to be linked to North Korea's Lazarus group.
- A breach in a developer's device at SafeWallet led to the hack.
- The FBI confirmed North Korean involvement in the Bybit hack, identifying a group named TraderTraitor.
- Bybit reported theft of 401,346 Ethereum on February 21.
- The FBI issued a warning about potential laundering of stolen assets into fiat.
- North Korea is suspected of orchestrating a $1.5 billion heist from Bybit.
- David Sacks divested over $200 million in digital assets before advising Trump on AI and cryptocurrencies.
- Private crypto venture deals fell to 116 in February 2025, a 60% drop from over 300 in October 2024.
- March investment surged to US$2.3 billion, including a US$2 billion investment in Binance by Abu Dhabi’s MGX, marking Binance’s first institutional investment.

title: Will the future of software development run on vibes?
summary:
- The term "vibe coding" was popularized by former OpenAI researcher Andrej Karpathy, referring to coding without fully understanding the code.
- AI tools like ChatGPT, Cursor Composer, GitHub Copilot, and Replit Agent enable this method by allowing users to describe programs in natural language.
- While vibe coding simplifies software creation for non-programmers, it raises concerns about code reliability and understanding, particularly in professional environments.

title: xAI Launches Image Generation API Amid Misinformation Concerns Over Grok
summary:
- Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, launched an image generation API called "grok-2-image-1212."
- The API can generate up to 10 images per request, limited to 5 requests per second, at $0.07 per image.
- xAI's pricing is competitive with Black Forest Labs ($0.05) and Ideogram ($0.08).
- No adjustments for image quality, size, or style are allowed; prompts can be revised by a "chat model."
- xAI seeks a $10 billion funding round, aiming for a $75 billion valuation while expanding its data center in Memphis.

- Users on X are looking for fact-checking from the AI bot Grok, raising concerns about misinformation.
- In March 2025, X enabled users to ask Grok questions, especially in politically sensitive contexts.
- Fact-checkers express worries that Grok may provide convincing but incorrect information.
- Five state secretaries have previously urged Musk to improve Grok's operations due to misinformation issues during U.S. elections.
- Unlike AI, human fact-checkers utilize credible sources and are accountable, enhancing transparency.
- Concerns about Grok's misrepresentation of information and lack of disclaimers lead to unverified claims.
- Skepticism exists regarding Grok's training data and quality control measures affecting response accuracy.
- Social media enables rapid spread of misleading information, raising awareness of its potential consequences.
- Research indicates AI can have error rates up to 20%, causing significant real-world impacts when misinformation occurs.
- The role of human fact-checkers is crucial despite AI advancements, with crowdsourced verification models being explored.

title: Europe Pushes for Better Non-Apple Smartwatch Compatibility with iPhones
summary:
- The EU has sent Apple preliminary instructions to comply with interoperability provisions in the Digital Markets Act (DMA).
- Apple must enable access to nine iOS connectivity features for third-party devices, improving compatibility.
- Apple argues the DMA's regulations could threaten user privacy and restrict innovation, calling them anti-competitive.
- The European Commission is instructing Apple to enhance iOS compatibility with third-party devices, including smartwatches and headphones.
- Two legally binding decisions were adopted under the Digital Markets Act (DMA) to allow greater access for app developers and device manufacturers to key iPhone features.
- Apple must provide technical documentation to help developers improve interoperability with iPhones and ensure a predictable review timeline for requests.
- The decisions represent the first concrete measures outlined for compliance with the DMA, according to Teresa Ribera, the EU's vice president for clean and competitive transition.
- Apple has the option to challenge these decisions in a judicial review.

title: Boston Dynamics Atlas Robot Evolution and Nvidia's Open Foundation Model Announcement
summary:
- Nvidia announced Isaac GR00T N1, an open-source model for humanoid robots.
- CEO Jensen Huang declared, "The age of generalist robotics is here."
- The framework emphasizes human-robot companionship rather than tool functionality.
- Demonstrations featured NEO Gamma robot using the GR00T N1 model.
- Early adopters include Boston Dynamics and Agility Robotics.
- GR00T N1 has a dual-system architecture: quick reflex actions and planning.
- Developers can customize the model using training data from human tasks.
- The model translates visual input into motor actions with a Diffusion Transformer at 120 Hz.
- It shows a 30% improvement in manipulation tasks.
- Demonstrated cross-embodiment capabilities with LeRobot SO100 robot arm.
- The initiative includes over 300,000 open-sourced simulated trajectories.

- The latest version is all-electric and capable of advanced machine learning tasks.
- Atlas demonstrated improved agility and flexibility, proving it can perform sorting tasks in a simulated environment.
- The robot now boasts enhanced sensors for better manipulation of objects.
- Boston Dynamics revealed the new Atlas as part of their commitment to create robots that can handle complex tasks without human intervention.
- Video footage displays Atlas performing various tasks, highlighting its unique capabilities and potential applications in real-world scenarios.
- The company hinted at future developments and the ongoing importance of robotics in industries such as construction and manufacturing.

title: Threat posed by new VMware hyperjacking vulnerabilities is hard to overstate
summary:
- Three critical vulnerabilities in VMware's virtual-machine products can allow hackers extensive access to sensitive environments.
- Known as hyperjacking or hypervisor attacks, these vulnerabilities let attackers break out of isolated VM environments and access multiple customers’ VMs.
- Security researcher Kevin Beaumont warns that escaping to the hypervisor enables access to all systems, disrupting boundaries that isolate customers.
- VMware has indicated that these vulnerabilities are actively being exploited and affect all supported and unsupported versions of its ESXi, Workstation, Fusion, Cloud Foundation, and Telco Cloud Platform.

title: Go Module Mirror served backdoor to devs for 3+ years
summary:
- A backdoored package was served via the Go Module Mirror by Google for over three years.
- The malicious version was named boltdb-go/bolt, targeting users of the legitimate boltdb/bolt module.
- The issue arose from typosquatting, where users could inadvertently download the backdoored package due to minor name variations.
- Researchers petitioned for its removal after spotting the malicious code, which was cached despite a revert to the legitimate version on GitHub.

title: Google Acquires Wiz for $33 Billion to Strengthen Cloud Security
summary:
- Google is acquiring cloud security startup Wiz for $33 billion, the largest acquisition in its history.
- The deal is pending regulatory approval and has not been officially confirmed by either company.
- Acquisition aims to strengthen Google's position in the enterprise cloud and security market, currently lagging behind AWS and Microsoft Azure.
- Wiz's projected annual recurring revenue (ARR) for this year is $1 billion, up from $500 million last year.
- If finalized, this acquisition will exceed Google's $12.5 billion purchase of Motorola Mobility in 2012.
- Wiz's products will remain available on competing platforms due to antitrust concerns.
- Google Cloud's market share is 12%, compared to AWS's 30% and Azure's 21%, hence a multicloud strategy is essential.
- SoftBank's investment in Wiz in August 2024 has resulted in tripling its initial investment value after the acquisition.
- Wiz, founded in 2020, services nearly 45% of Fortune 100 companies and raised $1 billion at a valuation exceeding $12 billion in May 2024.
- The company expects to achieve a $1 billion revenue rate by 2025.
- This acquisition is noted as the largest tech deal in Israel's history, reflecting a heightened interest in cybersecurity.
- Google’s growth in security services and the acquisition of Wiz may enhance its appeal to potential customers in the rapidly evolving AI and cloud landscape.

title: Overview of Tech Layoffs in 2024 and 2025
summary:
- Over 150,000 job cuts in 2024 across 542 tech companies.
- Significant layoffs at [Tesla](https://techcrunch.com/2024/04/15/tesla-layoffs-workers-sales-cybertruck-cuts/), [Amazon](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/10/amazon-prime-video-and-mgm-studios-laid-off-hundreds-of-employees/), [Google](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/10/google-cuts-hundreds-of-jobs-in-its-voice-assistance-hardware-teams-as-fitbit-founders-leave/), [TikTok](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/23/tiktok-lays-off-60-employees/), [Snap](https://techcrunch.com/2024/02/05/snapchats-parent-lays-off-10-of-workforce-in-order-to-reduce-hierarchy-says-company/), and [Microsoft](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/25/microsoft-lays-off-1900-employees-in-activision-blizzard-and-xbox-divisions/).
- Layoff trends expected to persist into 2025, as tracked by [Layoffs.fyi](https://layoffs.fyi/).
- A shift towards AI and automation is impacting large companies and startups alike.
- Monthly layoffs tracked from January 2024 to early 2025, with 6,003 jobs cut in January 2025 and 2,268 in December 2024.
- In 2025, over 22,000 tech workers laid off, including 16,084 in February alone.
- Significant layoffs also reported by NASA, Wayfair, and TikTok affecting hundreds of employees.
- Siemens to cut approximately 5,600 jobs globally, focused on automation and electric vehicles.
- HelloFresh plans to lay off 273 jobs in Texas as part of site consolidation.
- Additional notable layoffs include 340 at Wayfair and 2,500 at HPE due to financial adjustments.

title: Hyundai Mobis to mass-produce chips for EVs, smart lamps
summary:
- Hyundai Mobis plans to mass-produce in-vehicle chips for electrification and lamp systems.
- Increased demand for vehicle chips driven by electric vehicles (EVs) and autonomous driving technology.
- The company will focus on chips for EV power control and in-vehicle lamp operation.
- Modern vehicles may require around 3,000 semiconductor chips according to Hyundai Mobis.

sources.title: Hyundai Mobis to mass-produce chips for EVs, smart lamps

title: OpenAI, Google seek flexibility in South Korea’s AI law
summary:
- Representatives from OpenAI and Google requested flexibility in South Korea's AI Basic Act.
- The meeting involved representatives Sandy Kunvatanagarn (OpenAI) and Alice Hunt Friend, Eunice Huang (Google), alongside discussions led by Jared Ragland from BSA.
- The AI Basic Act will take effect in January 2026, following its passage in December 2024.
- This law is the second global AI law after the EU’s framework.
- The South Korean Ministry of ICT is currently drafting enforcement ordinances and clarifying operator liability and definitions of high-impact AI applications.

sources.title: OpenAI, Google seek flexibility in South Korea’s AI law

title: The Best iPhones in 2025: Which Apple Smartphone is Right for You
summary:
- The iPhone 16 is the best choice for most users, offering a balance of features at a lower price.
- iPhone 16 Pro is recommended for photography enthusiasts with its advanced camera features.
- iPhone 16 Pro Max is ideal for those seeking the best screen and battery life.
- The cheapest new iPhone is the iPhone 16e, suitable for budget-conscious buyers.
- All models feature the latest A18 chip, supporting AI tools and improved camera capabilities.
- The iPhone 16 introduces new features like a customizable Action button and improved water resistance.

title: LG Launches South Korea’s First Open-Source AI Model Exaone Deep; Grab CEO Highlights AI's Role in Business Growth
summary:
- Grab CEO Anthony Tan stressed the necessity of AI adoption at [Converge Live](https://www.techinasia.com/news/grab-ceo-warns-ai-crucial-for-growth-non-users-risk-lagging) in Singapore, warning non-users may lag behind.
- Grab's AI solutions include a 'driver co-pilot' for job optimization and reducing wait times, contributing to a 19% revenue increase to US$2.8 billion in 2024.
- Tan plans to expand AI use among Grab's 7,000 employees and personally uses AI for coding and productivity enhancements.
- [Roblox](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/17/roblox-releases-its-open-source-model-that-can-create-3d-objects-using-ai/) unveiled its open-source 3D model "Cube," leveraging generative AI for creating 3D objects, available for external developers.
- Cube allows users to generate objects like cars from simple text prompts and includes additional AI tools such as text generation and speech recognition.
- Future enhancements for Roblox aim to increase complexity in object generation and dynamic environmental changes.
- [LG](https://www.techinasia.com/news/lg-unveils-south-koreas-opensource-ai-model-exaone-deep) has introduced Exaone Deep, the first open-source AI model in South Korea.
- This model is designed to enhance AI development and research within the region.
- Exaone Deep aims to provide flexible and accessible AI tools for developers and researchers.

sources.title: Grab CEO warns AI crucial for growth, non-users risk lagging
Roblox releases its open-source model that can create 3D objects using AI
LG unveils South Korea’s first open-source AI model Exaone Deep

title: Kindle Colorsoft review: Amazon’s new e-reader gets colour screen upgrade
summary:
- The Kindle Colorsoft is Amazon's first e-reader with a colour screen, priced at £270.
- It offers improvements in contrast and speed over competitors like Boox and Kobo.
- Features a 7-inch colour e-paper display with 150ppi for colour and 300ppi for black & white.
- While black and white text appears a bit greyer, the functionality of the device remains solid.
- Enhanced visual organization with coloured book covers and in-text visuals, making it easier to browse.
- Supports highlighting passages in various colours, with a fast and responsive touchscreen interface.
- Battery life lasts approximately 32 hours when reading colour graphic novels.
- Weight is 219g, and dimensions are 127.6 x 176.7 x 7.8mm with IPX8 water resistance rating.
- Retains basic Kindle features with a smooth black plastic design and a single physical button.
- Although it enhances reading experiences, the small screen size makes it less ideal for full-size graphic novels.

sources.title: Kindle Colorsoft review: Amazon’s new e-reader gets colour screen upgrade

title: Bain Capital-backed Bridge Data Centres secures $2.8b loan deal
summary:
- Bridge Data Centres has secured a US$2.8 billion loan to support operations in Malaysia.
- This is the company’s largest bank financing arrangement to date.
- The five-year syndicated loan will refinance existing facilities and fund expansion.
- Bridge Data Centres is part of Wintrix, acquired by Bain Capital for US$3.2 billion in 2023.

title: Japan’s Metaplanet invests $12.5m worth of bitcoin + Trump's Crypto Strategic Reserve and Tariff Impact on Cryptocurrency
summary:
- President Trump announced new Crypto Strategic Reserve including Bitcoin, Ether, XRP, Solana, and Cardano.
- The Presidential Working Group is tasked with advancing the initiative.
- The SEC has relaxed regulations, dropping investigations into some cryptocurrencies.
- Trump's strategy aims to reduce regulatory hurdles for cryptocurrencies, utilizing taxpayer money in the reserve.
- Tariffs on imports are negatively impacting both stock and cryptocurrency markets.
- Metaplanet acquired 150 bitcoin for $12.5 million; aims for 10,000 BTC by end of 2025 and 21,000 BTC by 2026.
- Total holdings of Metaplanet are 3,200 BTC, valued at approximately $265.9 million.
- Metaplanet raised 2 billion yen ($13.3 million) through bond issuance to fund further bitcoin purchases.

title: Assassin’s Creed: Shadows – a historic frolic through feudal Japan
summary:
- Set in Japan, 1581, during the tumultuous era of Oda Nobunaga's reign.
- Combines exciting gameplay with a historical narrative as players take on the roles of a shinobi and a brave samurai.
- Features a richly detailed environment with authentic landscapes and historical settings, including Kyoto and Osaka.
- Offers dual protagonists: Fujibayashi Naoe, a stealthy female shinobi, and Yasuke, a powerful black samurai.
- Players navigate through missions that involve repetitive quest structures.
- Combat system praised for one-on-one engagements but criticized for chaotic group interactions.
- Game releases on March 20, priced at £59.99.

sources.title: Assassin’s Creed: Shadows – a historic frolic through feudal Japan
